PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

     The Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    This is essentially a consequential Bill. It follows on the passing of the Constitution of the Republic of Singapore (Amendment) Bill, 1991 on 3rd January. That Bill, apart from providing for the election of the President, also provided for GRCs to return either three or four MPs each.

    As I explained during the Second Reading debate on 4th October, 1990, this GRC provision is to facilitate a constituency which has grown between general elections to be served by an additional MP, if necessary, instead of breaking up the GRC.

    Parliament, in enacting the Constitution (Amendment) Bill, has approved this particular amendment. Consequently, we need to make similar amendments to the Parliamentary Elections Act.

    The amendment will give the Electoral Boundary Review Committee flexibility when it reviews electoral boundaries. This would minimise major changes of boundaries to GRCs which have grown too big for the number of MPs serving them.

    The Bill also seeks to change the upper limit of the number of MPs to be returned by all GRCS from one-half to three-quarters of the total number of elected MPs. At present, the number of MPs to be returned by GRCs cannot exceed one-half of the

Column: 780

total number of MPs to be returned at a general election. Since some GRCs will now have four MPs each, clause 3, sub-clause (c) of the Bill proposes that the maximum number of MPs to be returned by GRCs be increased from one-half to three-quarters of the total number of elected MPs. This is because it takes only two GRCs to have four MPs each to breach the upper limit of one-half, assuming that there is no change in the number of elected MPs. At present, 39 out of 81 elected MPs are returned by 13 GRCs. Hence, the need to change the upper limit of the number of MPs to be returned by GRCs from one-half to three-quarters of the total number of elected MPs.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh (Non-constituency Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, I did not touch on this subject during the debate on the Elected President. So now I wish to say a few words on this issue.

    This amendment, Sir, ostensibly reasonable, is directed at making it more difficult for the Opposition in elections. You will recall, Sir, that nearly three years ago, just when it feared that Opposition candidates might be elected in certain constituencies in the 1988 elections, the PAP introduced the system of Group Representation Constituencies (GRCs) which requires the election of three candidates together in one slate. And the PAP well knows that the creation of the GRCs had caused great difficulties for Opposition parties in the 1988 elections. The Workers Party, for instance, had to give up two GRCs which we had prepared to contest, at the very last moment when we had difficulties in getting the suitable candidates as stipulated in the amended Parliamentary Elections Act. As a result, the PAP candidates became MPs uncontested in those two GRCs.

    But in the last election, in spite of all its advantages, the PAP nearly lost in one GRC. It also had very close encounters in a few others with the Opposition parties. The PAP has therefore now thought it more prudent to make it still more difficult for the Opposition parties, all in order to

Column: 781

improve the chances for the PAP in future. Now using the excuse that there might be more voters staying in large constituencies, this amendment is introduced in the Parliamentary Elections Act to provide that GRCs shall elect groups of four Members of Parliament if the Government, ie, the PAP, so decides. And now the number of candidates in GRCs is going to be increased from three to four. I ask, Sir: is it fair to keep changing the rules of the game all the time?

    What is there to prevent it from further increasing the number to be elected in future GRCs, from four to five or even six, whenever the PAP should find it prudent to do so? Is that part of the new set of shared values now pushed by the PAP? If Government believes that there should be a more even spread of voters for the election of MPs, then the correct way is to institute a system of proportional representation. MPs become elected on the basis of the number of votes a party wins in an election. But it would appear that though the PAP Government waxes eloquent on shared values, it will still continue to place PAP interests above those of all others.

    In parliamentary elections, the PAP has never given Opposition parties a fair chance. This Bill is but yet another example.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, I rise to oppose this Bill.

    In principle, this Bill dilutes our democratic system. At first, we started with one man casting one vote for one candidate. The voter can vote for the person whom he wants to represent him in Parliament. But then the number was increased to three in a GRC - one vote is cast for three candidates. Where is the principle of representation when one vote is cast for three candidates? Because the voter may only want to vote for one of the candidates, and not the other two. So whether he likes it or not, he has to vote for the other two candidates. Now the position is even worse. You have to cast one vote for four candidates.

    The Goh Chok Tong Government says that it would encourage participatory democratic style of Government and I

Column: 782

support that. But, unfortunately, the ideal is inconsistent with the action taken so far. It would appear that only lip-service is given to this principle of participatory democratic style of Government. How can there by participatory style when you cast one vote for four candidates? In fact, the participation in this democratic exercise has been reduced.

    It is obvious, like the sentiments given by Dr Lee, that the purpose is to make it difficult for the Opposition. The PAP has tried everything - from Elected President, NMP, to now having four candidates, instead of three, in a GRC. Instead of having this dilution, the Government should show its sincere intent on having more real participation from the people and there can only be real participation in the democratic process if there are more Opposition Members in Parliament, and not to keep them out. What we want is really a two-party system in Singapore. More opposition and there shall be real participation on the part of the people and it should not try to close the doors and make it more difficult for elected Opposition members to be in Parliament.

    The Government has tried everything - from Elected President, NCMP, NMP and the lot. But I think the Government is going to find it difficult because the people do want real representation in Parliament, as indicated by the increase in the number of votes for the Opposition in the last election. If the Government is not careful - I think it should heed the warning - the people would say enough is enough and I think there will be a backlash on the Government. The number of candidates for the Opposition in the next election, whether there are four candidates in a GRC or not, I think the people will definitely not agree with the Government and they will elect more Opposition candidates.

    It is quite obvious why the Government wants to have four MPs in a GRC. I think their intent is to finally make the whole of Singapore Group Representation Constituencies instead of having single constituencies. Then the number of minority representation would be about 25%. If the Government intends to make Potong Pasir a GRC, I would certainly welcome that.

Column: 783



     The Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I find that there are contradictions in both Mr Chiam as's well as Dr Lee Siew-Choh's argument that we are making things more difficult for the Opposition. If Dr Lee Siew-Choh sincerely believes that we are making things more difficult for him now, as well as in the last election, can he explain to this House why then did he choose to stand in a GRC? He had plenty of single-member constituencies to choose from, but he chose to stand in Eunos GRC. That tells us that he believed that his chances of winning in that election were much better in a GRC. He has therefore contradicted himself.

    The answer to the Opposition MPs' problem is to find more candidates. If they can find more candidates and their candidates are as good as the PAP's, then they would not be worrying whether it is a single-member constituency or GRC. Do not blame your problems on what we are doing over here, which is to make things easier under certain circumstances for the Electoral Boundary Review Committee when it comes to reviewing electoral boundaries.

    I would not want to enter into a debate on proportional representation over here because it is irrelevant to the debate this afternoon. If Dr Lee Siew-Choh believes that proportional representation is good for Singapore, he can always bring this matter up either in a Question for oral answer or in an Adjournment Motion, or even in a motion before the House and we can have it debated.

    Mr Chiam hopes that Potong Pasir will be made into a GRC. That is a contradiction, because if he thinks we are making things more difficult for him, why does he hope that Potong Pasir should be made into a GRC?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: There will be a backlash. I said so.

     The Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Mr Goh Chok Tong): If he thinks there will be a backlash because of the change in have more GRCs, surely he and Dr Lee Siew-Choh should welcome our

Column: 784

stupid move, is it not? Because it must be the height of absurdity for me to miscalculate or misjudge the electorate. I think he does not believe that we have made a mistake in our judgment.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. - [The Prime Minister and Minister for Defence].

    Bill considered in Committee.

"Amendment of        Section 20 of the principal Act is

section 20.          amended by inserting, immediately after

                     subsection (2), the following subsection:

                     "(3) Where a new electoral division is

                     created under section 8 by the amalgamation

                     of the whole of two or more existing

                     electoral divisions, or where there is no

                     change in the boundary of any electoral

                     division specified in a notification under

                     section 8(1), section 10 shall not apply to

                     that electoral division unless the Minister

                     otherwise directs; and the certified

                     registers of electors in operation for those

                     existing electoral divisions which have been

                     of electors in operation for that new

                     election.".". - [The Prime Minister and

                     Minister for Defence].


    Brought up, and read the First time.

     The Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the clause be read a Second time."

    Sir, I have earlier explained that, following the provisions of the Constitutional amendments on the Elected President, we have to amend the Parliamentary Elections Act so that a GRC can return either three or four MPs each.

Column: 785



    A new GRC for three or four MPs can be created in several other ways. First, parts of two or more constituencies can be carved up and joined to create a new constituency. In that case, the boundaries of several constituencies will obviously be affected. It is clear in such a case that there will be a need for a new register of voters. This is because the names of voters in the newly created constituency will be found in various parts of other registers.

    Another situation could be where the entire of two or more single-member constituencies are joined up to form a new GRC constituency.

    A third scenario is where an existing GRC (without any change to its boundary) is joined up with another single-member constituency.

    In the second and third situations, since it is the whole of the constituencies which are being merged, and since there is no splitting up of any constituency, their existing registers of voters would be unaffected and can still be used. However, section 10 of the Parliamentary Elections Act, read with section 8, would require new registers of electors to be created even for the second and third situations which I described. This requirement is really not necessary.

    To illustrate: suppose all the registers of electors had been revised in December 1993. Suppose we then decide to have general elections in the first quarter of 1994. Suppose some new constituencies are created purely by the amalgamation of the whole of two or more existing constituencies. It does not make sense that we have to republish all the registers for the new amalgamated constituencies. All we need to do is just to use the current registers of those constituencies which have been amalgamated as the register for the newly-created constituency. The same should apply for existing constituencies where there is no change to the boundaries, eg, where it is decided to have four MPs instead of three in a GRC.

    The amendment before the Committee is to meet this point. It provides that where a new constituency is created by amalgamating the whole of two or more constituencies, the existing registers of voters

Column: 786

for those constituencies will be taken as the register for the new constituency. This will also be the case for any existing constituency whose boundary has not changed. This applies to both single-member constituencies and GRCs.

    The amendment also gives the discretion to the Minister to direct otherwise. This is in case the registers are not current and should be updated. This is consistent with the provision in section 10 giving the discretion to the Minister.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Clause read a Second time and added to the Bill.

     The Chairman: This new clause is to be inserted immediately after clause 3. Existing clauses 4 to 8 will be renumbered as clauses 5 to 9 respectively.

    Bill reported with an amendment; read a Third time and passed.

SINGAPORE ARMED FORCES (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

     The Second Minister for Defence (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, the Constitution of the Republic of Singapore (Amendment) Act was recently passed by this House. As Members are aware, the Constitutional amendments empower the President to safeguard the integrity and the competence of the public service.

    Article 21 of the Constitution provides that the appointment and revocation of appointments to the offices of Chief of Defence Force, Chiefs of Army, Navy and Air Force require the President's concurrence, acting in his own discretion.

    This Bill seeks as a consequential amendment to amend the Singapore Armed Forces Act to bring the appointment of the Chief of Defence Force, the Chiefs of Army, Navy and Air Force in line with the provisions of the Constitution of the Republic of Singapore (Amendment) Act.

Column: 787



    The Bill proposes that these appointments and revocations be made on the advice of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister will be required to consult the Armed Forces Council before tendering his advice to the President. This is to ensure that the Prime Minister will have the benefit and the experience of the Armed Forces Council in his choice of nominees.

    The Bill also spells out the composition of the Armed Forces Council. The Armed Forces Council is the highest policy making body which oversees the administration of the Singapore Armed Forces. At present, the Singapore Armed Forces Act only specifies that the Armed Forces Council shall consist of the Minister as Chairman and such other members as the Minister appoints. To ensure the continued integrity and competence of the Armed Forces Council, this Bill proposes that the Armed Forces Council consist of:

    (a) The Minister charged with the responsibility for Defence, and any other Ministers who have been assigned to assist him.

    (b) The key officers in MINDEF and the SAF, namely, the Permanent Secretary or Secretaries of the Ministry of Defence, the Chief of Defence Force, the Chiefs of Army, Navy and Air Force.

    (c) In addition, not more than four other non-ex officio members can be appointed by the President if he concurs with the advice of the Prime Minister. Sir, such non-ex officio members can assist the Armed Forces Council with their special expertise and experience.

    The Bill also makes amendments in a number of other matters, resulting from working experience with the Singapore Armed Forces Act over the years.

    Sir, many Singaporeans volunteer to serve in the SAF. This is very commendable. This Bill brings volunteers into the mainstream of the SAF, so that volunteers will now enjoy the same status as SAF national servicemen and regulars. This is in contrast to their previous status under the People's Defence Force Act.

Column: 788



    Sir, there are presently two types of fact-finding bodies convened in the SAF. They are the Boards of Inquiry and Committees of Inquiry. Boards of Inquiry can only consist of members of the Singapore Armed Forces, whereas a Committee of Inquiry can include non-members of the SAF.

    It has been the practice of the SAF to convene Committees of Inquiry (COI) where a matter of public interest is involved. In such cases, the COI is usually chaired by a civilian and may include other civilians from outside MINDEF. This Bill strengthens the Committees of Inquiry with the powers to summon witnesses and administer oaths and provides for procedures similar to those of a Board of Inquiry.

    Under section 111 of the existing SAF Act, there is a time bar of three years from the time of commission for most offences, beyond which no disciplinary action can be taken against the offender. Presently, only two offences, namely, mutiny and desertion are not subjected to this time bar.

    Sir, this Bill proposes that two additional offences, namely, misconduct in action and assisting the enemy, both punishable by death, should also not be subjected to the time bar as these are very serious offences.

    Currently, if a serviceman is not charged for Absent Without Official Leave (AWOL) within three years, or he has gone AWOL for more than three years, he can only be charged with the more serious offence of desertion. Sometimes, there are strong mitigating circumstances where it is more appropriate to charge such a serviceman with the lesser offence of AWOL. Sir, this Bill removes the time bar for AWOL offences and will give Mindef the flexibility to bring the lesser charge against the offending serviceman.

    In the SAF, military offences are either dealt with summarily by a Disciplinary Officer or by a Subordinate Military Court. At present, an active serviceman can only be tried summarily within six months from the date of the offence. However, there may be cases where the detection or the

Column: 789

investigation of the offence takes more than six months and hence it passes the six-month time bar. In such cases, the only recourse available is trial by court martial. This normally carries a heavier penalty.

    Sir, this Bill gives the Armed Forces Council the discretion in specific cases to raise the time bar for summary trials. However, there will be an upper limit of three years from the time of offence beyond which summary trial cannot take place.

    Finally, Sir, the current scale of fines prescribed in the SAF was instituted in 1972. In line with revised penalties for civilian offences, the Bill proposes to revise the scale of fines, to retain their deterrent effects.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

     Mr Charles Chong (Sembawang GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for giving me this opportunity to speak on this Bill.

    The GPC for Defence is generally supportive of the rationale and the objectives of the Singapore Armed Forces (Amendment) Bill. It is recognised that most of the proposed amendments are consequential changes relating to the recent constitutional amendment on the Elected President. Other amendments proposed are mainly related to the updating and rationalisation of existing provisions in the Singapore Armed Forces Act. However, with your kind permission, Sir, I would like to take this opportunity to comment on a few provisions in the Bill.

    The proposed section 8(2) of the Bill makes it clear that the Minister for Defence shall be the Chairman of the Armed Forces Council. Sir, I think it would be prudent that when the Minister for Defence is also the Prime Minister the functions of the Chairman of the Armed Forces Council should be performed by a Minister or a Minister of State who is a member of the Armed Forces Council, other than the Prime Minister. The reason for this is that the new section 10A(1) and (2) of the Bill requires the Prime Minister to consult the Armed Forces Council on the appointment or revocation of appointment of the Chief

Column: 790

of Defence Force and the Chiefs of the Army, Air Force and Navy before he advises the President. If the Prime Minister is also the Minister for Defence and consequently Chairman of the Armed Forces Council, a situation may arise where the Prime Minister may have to consult himself before he advises the President.

    Sir, Article 37B(4) of our newly amended Constitution stipulates that the Chairman of the Council of Presidential Advisors whenever he performs the functions of the President, shall not act as Chairman of the Council simultaneously. The provision of this Article in the Singapore Constitution is perhaps to prevent a situation where a key office holder becomes his own advisor. Therefore, I think it would be appropriate that a similar provision should be drafted in the Armed Forces Act to avoid a situation where the Prime Minister acts as his own advisor.

    Sir, I would also like to comment on the new section 8B(2) of the Bill which states that where the Chairman of the Armed Forces Council is not present at any meeting of the Council, no business shall be transacted. New subsection (3) goes on further to state that even if the Chairman had appointed a member of the Council to act on his behalf, no decision of the Council on any matter made at the meeting can take effect until the written consent of the Chairman has been obtained. The requirements of section 8B therefore appear to be somewhat restrictive and may unnecessarily delay implementation of decisions of the Armed Forces Council if ever the Minister for Defence is away or not available for any length of time.

    Sir, in our attempt to create more checks and balances on authority, which invariably will serve us well under normal circumstances, we should also consider provisions to ensure that in times of crisis, these checks and balances will not stifle independent initiative and delay implementation of critical decisions required to save the situation under abnormal circumstances. Perhaps the Minister could provide clarification and also some assurance that the requirements stipulated in new section 8B of the Bill will not be a hindrance to the operations of the Armed Forces Council, especially in times of crisis

Column: 791

or emergency, when the Minister for Defence is not available.

    Sir, the GPC for Defence welcomes the proposed section 8C of the Singapore Armed Forces (Amendment) Bill. This new section will empower the Armed Forces Council to appoint committees for general or specific purposes, including disciplinary matters and to conduct inquiries. Such committees would be entrusted with similar powers as that provided to a Board of Inquiry. I feel that this is a very timely amendment in view of the recent number of accidents involving SAF personnel, some of which have unfortunately resulted in fatalities.

    Sir, but let us not forget that we never allowed the free market to operate when we sent our best scholars to study chosen academic fields that would contribute directly to economic growth. The free market would have turned much of this talent into contractors or stockbrokers, because that was where the easy money was. Our Government intervened, and rightly so, to ensure that those who could best contribute to the economy gained the pecuniary and social rewards for their contribution. This emphasis was particularly necessary in the past when we were struggling to enter into the ranks of the NICs.

    We must of course continue to promote and recognise such economic talent. But alongside this, we must also produce

Column: 827

writers, artists, entertainers and athletes who are well paid and well praised. In practical terms, let us have more scholarships and subsidies for talented young people to go into the creative arts, journalism, entertainment and so forth. Let us promote culture and the arts with ever more vigour - and more money - so that such talent will find a more receptive market. Let us also recognise them publicly with better media coverage, invitations to Istana receptions, National Day functions, and so on.

    My suggestion for this shared value, that of recognising talent and gifts of all kinds that are beneficial to society, would be, "Equal opportunities for all."

    With a broader recognition of talents from all quarters of society, our people will gain greater self-esteem and find it less daunting to seek fulfilment in life. Parents whose children do not score enough distinctions in school examinations need not wring their hearts in despair. The child, if he is encouraged, will find success in another field for which he is talented and for which he should be respected.

    One mark of a cohesive and mature nation is indeed that few of its people feel left out or lack self-esteem for not having gained social recognition in their vocations. It is a foolish government that leaves the majority of its people feeling not appreciated or respected for their individual talents and contributions. If these people become plagued by a sense of inferiority or failure, the government too would have failed.

    Sir, I urge that this notion of equal opportunity and esteem for all talents that contribute to the social good be enshrined in our system of shared values.

    Sir, the statement of Shared Values in the White Paper, with some amendments and refinement, could serve as the basis of our nation building for generations. I commend it to the House.

     The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Sir, may I thank all the Members

Column: 828

who have contributed to the discussion, as well as all those outside of this chamber whose inputs have helped us to formulate the Shared Values for Singaporeans over the last two years. We have deliberately taken some time over the Shared Values proposal, because it is a very difficult exercise. There are two conflicting requirements which we have to meet.

    Firstly, it is a sensitive subject. For the exercise to succeed, the Shared Values cannot be controversial. They must enjoy wide consensus support. If this is an exciting discussion, then we have already made our task more difficult. But secondly, neither can the Shared Values be mere platitudes, what one Member earlier called "motherhood" statements. They cannot just be a general list of virtues, with no practical meaning. They have to convey something significant to Singaporeans.

    We have tried to combine these two opposing requirements in one White Paper. Our aim is to identify values which have us to succeed as one nation, so that we can pass them on to future generations, and gradually develop a common Singaporean identity.

    Originally, we had four values - society, family, consensus and harmony. After the discussions, we modified one: "Society above self" became "Nation before community and society above self". We added one to cover the individual: "Regard and community support for the individual" This gives us five items - the nation, the family, the individual, consensus and harmony. The sequence is a logical one, but it does not indicate their relative importance of the five values. As some MPs have pointed out, perhaps the first one on "Society above self" and the last one on "Racial and religious harmony" are the crucial ones, because without these two, all the rest mean nothing.

    These five values are compatible with the traditions of the vast majority of Singaporeans, whatever their race or religion. Chinese scholars feel that they reflect Confucian ideals, and some have said they are Confucian values. But they are also compatible with Islam, Christianity and Hinduism. So some people have called them universal values. We did not choose these

Column: 829

values because of any particular name which they had, but because they reflect the heritage of Singaporeans, and have contributed to our success as a nation. They may not be unique to us, but they are relevant to Singaporeans. I think we should uphold them and strengthen them. We should make them Singaporean values.

    If you take all five together, this group of ideas emphasises putting society above self. In other words, they are communitarian values. That is basic. We start by asking ourselves the question: Does society exist for the sake of the individuals which are inside it? Or is this group, the society, something more than the sum total of the livelihoods of its members? There is no universally right or wrong answer to this question. Every society has to ask it, and every society has to answer it. Each one does so in its own different way. The two extreme positions are, on the one hand, individualism, and on the other, communitarianism.

    Individualism, which is the same idea as liberalism, holds that it is the individuals, not the groups, who are the significant actors. The people matter, one by one, not the society as a whole as one organism. The society, the group, has no intrinsic value or significance in itself; its value lies, solely in the individual members who make it up. The state is simply the means by which these individuals within it realise their potentials and fulfil their aspirations. It is a convenient way for individuals to get what they need, what they want, what they aspire to. But more than that it is nothing - it is just a tool. It is what they call a social contract, meaning an agreement amongst its citizens who have gotten together to provide themselves with certain shared services, like defence and public order. We all need it, we cannot do it separately, well, let us agree, sign a contract, we hire an armed force, provide for all of us. Beyond that, what is not specified in the contract, the society has no right to. That is one extreme: individualism.

    The other extreme is communitarianism, also called corporatism in a recent pair of articles in the Straits Times by two academics from the National University of

Column: 830

Singapore. Corporatism emphasises the importance and the well-being of the society as a whole. In this view, the society comes first. The individual has rights, yes, but he also has duties. He has a standing and a worth, not because of his own merits, but because he happens to belong to a society. His place in that society, what he does in it, gives his life meaning and value. To take him out from the society, standing by himself, no matter how talented and how able he is, he loses that meaning and worth. In fact, some people will say he loses that purpose in life.

    This division between an individualistic society and a communitarian society has nothing to do with democracy. A country which puts the group above the individual can be a democracy, just as a country which puts the individual first can be a democracy. If you are going to put group interests first, then you must determine what group interests are. It is not what one or two people say. It is what the people as a whole feel. There is no ideal way to do this, but the best way is through the ballot - let the people express their will, let them choose leaders who will carry out their wishes, and let them then decide whether these leaders have served them well. You can even argue that if democracy is to work well, then the citizens cannot be totally individualistic. To some degree, they have to be prepared to put the country first, and to put aside some of their differences in order to achieve common goals.

    These are the two logical extremes - individualism and communitarianism. In reality, every society lies somewhere in between these two extremes, and gives some weight to both of these values; both to the individual and to the community. The only question which we have to decide is where exactly to pitch that balance. How much weight to give to each one?

    For many Asian societies, the balance has always been tilted towards the society as a whole. Japan is the clearest example of a country where the individuals all feel that they are part of the group, and the group is far more important than any individual Japanese. But we should

Column: 831

remember that putting society first is not a uniquely Asian idea. You will have heard this phrase, "No man is an island, entire of itself". It was not expressed by Confucius or any Asian philosopher. It was an Englishman who said it, John Donne, a 17th century churchman and poet.

    Right now, of course, individualism happens to be the dominant philosophy in the West. The US is the leading example of an individualistic society. Most Americans are quite convinced that this is the right solution for them. It suits the US, it suits their history, it suits the temperament of their people, it suits their position in the international order. Perhaps they are right. Some Americans would go further and claim that all mankind should do likewise. I personally think that is probably not right. But there are also a few American scholars - Dr Ong earlier mentioned Professor George Lodge - who think that individualism is precisely the cause of the economic troubles which the United States is now undergoing. These scholars believe that individualism is an inferior way to organise society and to generate economic growth. You have many brilliant ideas, many sparks of genius, but you cannot gather these sparks together and kindle them into a blazing fire. So they argue that the US needs more communitarianism to compete against Japan, to compete against East Asian countries. They include Singapore amongst the East Asian countries which the Americans must compete against, but I think we flatter ourselves if we pitch our position quite so high.

    Where does Singapore stand? We also have both strands in our tradition. We believe in developing each individual to his or her fullest potential. We value our citizens, not just because they happen to be useful to the country, but because we believe that each person is intrinsically worthy of respect. In economic matters, we depend on competition and on free markets to make each person give of his best. We do not believe in the communist ethic: to each according to his need; from each according to his con-

Column: 832

tribution. We believe that people will perform best when they are rewarded according to their contribution and when they compete furiously against others in order to do well. That is the individualistic strand in our national ethos.

    But Singapore has not succeeded by being an individualistic society. We depend on cooperation and teamwork amongst ourselves so that we will do well not just as individual Singaporeans, but as the Singapore team, competing against other nations. We have succeeded as a nation because we have repeatedly pulled together to overcome adversity, and put the nation's interests first.

    In fact, the very idea of individualism is alien to our mother tongues. For example, there is no native Malay word for the concept "Individualism". I looked it up, the Malay word used is "individualisme". It is imported directly from English. There is a Chinese phrase, " " (ge ren zhu yi). It conveys the meaning of the word, but it carries negative overtones and it suggests selfishness. It is an undesirable trait. We are a society which has always put the community before the individual.

    I think there is more to this than simply finding the best way to fulfil each individual. There is some value in the nation of Singapore which is more than the sum of the individual livelihoods of Singaporeans. Consider this hypothetical scenario. Suppose some day something happens to Singapore, as happened to Kuwait. As a result, Singaporeans find themselves dispersed, scattered all over the world, in America, Canada, Australia, Europe, Britain, China, India. But suppose like the Kuwaitis, we still manage to keep our living, so that while we are scattered around the world, we are personally and physically not hardup. If you are an engineer, you are an engineer in America. If you are a technician, you are a technician in Australia. If you are a lawyer, you are practising in the United Kingdom. You have your livelihood, you have a family. This is what happened to the Kuwaitis. They are overseas, they are scattered. But do you think they feel happy? Do you think we would feel happy scattered like this? I doubt it. Surely we will feel that some important part of us is lost - the sense of togetherness and identity, the sense of

Column: 833

being in charge of our own future, the sense of being one nation, one Singapore.

    So we need to put society above self, and not only out of enlightened self-interest. An individual Singaporean fulfils himself not only on his own, but by being part of a living society, and by contributing to this living society, each one in his own way. As Dr Hong Hai says, whether you are an artist, whether you are a dancer, whether you are a radio announcer or a corporate chieftain, all are deserving of respect. We need to learn many things from Western civilisation. But we should be careful not to adopt individualistic values blindly, just because they happen to be the current fashion in the West.

    So this has been the overall thrust of the Shared Values. It is a thrust which has been confirmed by the vast majority of the people who have participated in discussions and expressed their views on this matter. However, we have modified the individual values to take in the suggestions and the views which various people have expressed.

    The first value - "society above self" - we have modified by adding in the idea of "nation before community". It is one important part of putting the nation first, putting society first. The nation must come not only before the individual, but also before the interests of any sub-group. We are doing our best to keep our individual cultural heritages alive - the Chinese, Indian and Malay. Every time you see a lion dance or kompang or a Deepavali celebration, we are keeping our separate cultures alive. It is necessary, because we cannot, and we should not, cook up a new unique Singaporean culture overnight. It is not like blending a new perfume and giving it a name. But we must not allow this seeking of roots to draw us apart. We are all, first and foremost, Singaporeans.

    There is another aspect to putting the nation before the community, and that is, racial and religious harmony is not just a matter of being polite and sensitive to other people. Yes, you have to be polite and sensitive, but you also need to subordinate the interests of your own group to the overall interests of Singapore. If you are lording it over the others, no matter

Column: 834

how polite you are, race and religious relations will become tense. For example, if the Chinese, who happen to be in the majority, push for Singapore to become a predominantly Chinese society, this must lead to trouble, because the minorities will feel threatened, they will mobilise in response, and the polarisation cannot easily be undone. Fortunately, the Chinese have not done this, although from time to time Chinese chauvinists have tried to stir up the ground. And the same will happen even if a minority group puts its group interests first before the nation. Dr Hong Hai says these are painful dilemmas, very difficult situations for people to face. But they are real dilemmas which from time to time life put before us, and we do have to choose. They are not hypothetical situations.

    Although the thrust of the Shared Values is on the society, we added one value to emphasise the importance of the individual, and that is, "Regard and community support for the individual". It helps to round out the set of values and give it proper balance. We want to tilt the balance slightly, towards the society and the group, and away from the individual. But as one of my colleagues pointed out, the Shared Values are not just the delta, the direction in which we want to move. We are specifying the end position, what is the final balance. We want that to be a reasonable mean, not an extreme.

    Somebody said that "Regard and community support" did not make it clear enough. Maybe we should use the word "respect" - Respect and community support for the individual. We can consider such amendment. It is not too late. If we fail to point out that the individual deserves respect and consideration in his own right, then we risk over-emphasising the demands of society, and riding roughshod over the intrinsic rights of individual Singaporeans.

    The other limb of this value stresses that the community ought to support the individual, especially those in most need of help. It does not say, "Support for the needy. Support for the poor. Support for the handicapped", because the community supports all of us to varying degrees,

Column: 835

whether you are able to look after yourself, or whether you need a greater degree of assistance and propping up. We have to look after one another, both as a society, and also as individual human beings.

    How do you do this? How do you help the needy and those who cannot look after themselves? That is a difficult problem in every society. The experience of many countries, both in the East and in the West, is that this should be done and organised on a mutual help basis, by volunteers and community groups. This is the way to keep the obligation personal, to channel the help sensitively and accurately to those individuals who needed most.

    That is in fact the Singapore tradition - self-help, many helping hands. It is the Singapore way, shared by all our major communities. The Chinese clan associations have always played an active role in community affairs, especially in the early days of the colonial government. The Indians also have sub-ethnic organisations, like the Tamil Representatives Council and the Singapore Khalsa Association, and others. And the Malays have a tradition of gotong royong. It started in the kampungs, as the kampung spirit, but even when the Malays moved out of the kampungs and into HDB areas, they still organised welfare committees and Muslim benevolent associations.

    So the spirit is alive. We should keep them alive, and we should avoid bringing in the State. Because when the State steps in, it brings in bureaucracy, it brings in rigid rules, and the support becomes depersonalised. You have to do according to what the book says. You cannot do according to what you, as a community leader on the spot, knows need to be done, which cannot necessarily be justified in dollars and cents according to exact formulas and procedures. As a result, the support misses those who needed most, and goes instead to those who are less in need. Eventually, there develops a psychology of entitlements, a crutch mentality. When that happens, the best-intentioned help becomes counter-productive.

Column: 836



    It is not a hypothetical danger. It has happened in every developed society which has set up a welfare state. Invariably at the beginning they have set up welfare states with the best of intentions and with the most careful caveats that they are extending a helping hand, not giving alms, that they are equalizing opportunities, not results, that they want people to work, not to beg. But it is in the dynamic of the situation that once the State moves in, by degrees and imperceptibly, the trends grow and eventually all the ills of a welfare state develop. We must not repeat their mistake.

    I come to the fourth value now - "Consensus instead of contention". It has been the most controversial one, but I suspect that is because it has been misunderstood. Promoting consensus does not mean suppressing dissent, or discouraging debate. It means that we should discuss issues widely, but in a spirit of give and take, so that we will find solutions which accommodate the views and concerns of as many Singaporeans as possible. I read in the papers that Mr Chiam See Tong talked about "thesis, antithesis, synthesis". That is dialectical materialism. It is a bit out of fashion, but it is still correct. That is precisely what we are looking for - a view, an opposing view, and a creative synthesis of the two, which would embody the best aspects of both.

    But, of course, in the process of trying that, you may end up with argument, counter-argument, and impasse, then we are in trouble.

    When 2.8 million people discuss a subject, unanimity will not happen very often. We cannot refrain from doing something which is in the interests of the vast majority, just because a small minority is not yet satisfied. But even when we cannot reach one common understanding, we should respect the opposing viewpoint, and agree to disagree amicably. We should not break up into feuding factions, which are unable to reconcile our differences. Because today we have this issue, tomorrow we remain Singaporeans together, and we have to discuss other issues. And while we disagree on one item, we may well find ourselves allies on

Column: 837

another. Much less should we make enemies out of one another.

    In every society there are disputes and differences of opinions, over private matters, over commercial affairs, over great issues of state. It is only natural and healthy. Without constructive debate, without a lively exchange of views, no society can hope to break new ground and make progress. But societies differ in the ways by which they seek to resolve differences of views. Some try to conciliate opposing views and smooth over the differences; others fight it out in adversarial proceedings in court. They believe that out of sound and fury will come sweetness and light. Again, the Japanese and the Americans present opposing examples. Just look at the number of lawyers each of these two countries has. The Americans have one lawyer for every 360 Americans. The Japanese have one lawyer for every 9,300 Japanese. That is, Americans have 26 times as many lawyers per capita as Japan. Are they 26 times happier? Should we follow the American, or the Japanese example?

    That is what we mean by consensus instead of contention. This value refers generally to relationship within Singaporean society, not just the relation between the Government and the people. But consensus is also what the Government has been trying to achieve. I know that some people still feel the Government is too hard and unforgiving in its approach, intolerant, harsh. They would like the Government to be gentler and more consensual, smile more often, follow the heart rather than the head more often. We will try to be gentler and more consensual. So long as everybody accepts what the end objective is, and that is, to discover the best course for the country, then we can work together in order to achieve a common goal.

    Some people have suggested that the phrasing of this value can be improved.

    The problem is more with the wording of it than with the sentiment. There have not been any complaints about the Chinese or the Malay versions. The Chinese version says " " (Qiu

Column: 838

Tong Cun Yi Xie Shang Gong Shi). The Malay version says "Permuafakatan bukan Pertikaian". The reservation has been over the word "contention". Some feel that it is too wide. Contention may be good, contention may be bad. It is not too late to amend the language, if MPs can come up with a better word than "contention". We can consider, eg. "Consensus instead of strife", or "Consensus instead of confrontation", or "Consensus instead of discord", or "Consensus not conflict". There are any number of bad words to express the idea. Let us find a suitable one. MPs should discuss this and perhaps we can decide the issue tomorrow. Somebody can move an amendment, and we can agree on a revised formulation of the five values.

    The Shared Values leave out religious values, in order to keep the state and religion clearly separate. This does not mean that religion is unimportant, or that the Government has anything against religion. On the contrary, I believe that religion is a major factor for social cohesion and stability. All religions enjoin their followers to do good, and to care for their fellow human beings. But Singapore is a secular state. The state should not venture into the religious realm, and prescribe religious values for its citizens, no matter how generalised these may be. Because if the state is entitled to prescribe generalised religious values, then so too religious leaders must be entitled to prescribe generalised political values. And that way lies trouble.

    Several people have argued that although Singapore is a secular state, we should nevertheless include religious values in the Shared Values and, particularly, "Belief in God". I do not think this is wise. In fact, all the religious leaders who have commented on the Shared Values have advised us against doing this. I will just quote one, Brother Joseph McNally, who wrote a letter to Mr Goh Chok Tong two years ago, in which he said:

    "Religions themselves are agents of social harmony and valuable to Society so long as they recognise the right of other religions to coexist with them. Society encourages the practice of religion but retains the right to suppress any religion that preaches against another and thereby disrupts harmony.

Column: 839



    What interests Society is not religion as such but rather the philosophy which derives from it. Society does not practise a religion; the individual does. So far as Society is concerned, religion is a private matter. It accepts the right of each individual to practise any religion or no religion. Society insists that positive respect be shown by each individual to the religion of the other person and takes action against individuals who seek to denigrate other religions or to force their religion on others.". I think that is a wise approach which we should follow.

    We have also left out political items - good government, meritocracy, democracy, and so on - from these Shared Values. Again it is not because these are unimportant. All Singaporeans should absorb these values, whether or not they support the government of the day. But these values represent a separate set of ideas from those which are expressed in the five Shared Values. The five Shared Values presently deal with the relationship between the individual and the society. If we are going to cover political values adequately, we would have to add another four or five items to the list, at least - democracy, good government, meritocracy, equal opportunities, pursuit of excellence. We would lose focus, and end up dealing adequately with neither area.

    Nevertheless, we must find other avenues to inculcate political values systematically among the population and especially among young Singaporeans. Every schoolboy and schoolgirl should grow up with a common understanding of the basic facts of political life - that Singapore is small, that it depends on exports to other countries to make a living, that it is through ceaseless endeavour in the pursuit of excellence that we can do well and get ahead. The Japanese do this in their schools. They make sure that every young Japanese grows up understanding Japan's place in the world.

    There was recently a programme on Japan in the BBC entitled "Nippon", the first in a series. They showed a little bit of how the Japanese do this. A commentator who said this:

    'Six thousand miles away, Japan's own agricultural heartland lies in the rice paddies of Nigata prefecture. Each spring school children are taken to the fields by

Column: 840

the older people of the village to be taught the traditional method of planting rice by hand that has sustained the Japanese for thousands of years. Although most planting is by machine these days, this is a deliberate lesson in values and hard work. It's designed to pass on to the children the age-old view that the Japanese people have had of themselves.'

    Then in a classroom, this is what the teacher said:

    'Look at this map of the world, please. This is Japan. It's a small island country surrounded on all sides by sea. Japan has very few of its own natural resources. And so it imports resources from other countries. When we say we import natural resources, we mean that we buy them and bring them home.'

    That is how they bring the lesson home. Then it quotes Kenichi Ohmae. He is a pundit who writes on these issues and he said:

    'What they teach is, we are a small nation, lots of people to feed, no natural resources. This means that you have to borrow money to buy raw materials, add value and export. The difference in price is going to give you the money to buy food. Therefore those who do not work to that value shall not eat. So that's the raison d'etre of this country. And if you are taught like this, you keep exporting and hope that you earn money and then you eat well. That is the Japanism. And everything we do is related to this notion.' So we must find some ways to do that.

    The Ministry of Education will be incorporating political values in its civics programme. It has asked Dr Goh Keng Swee who has agreed to write up a series of lectures, to put across these ideas in ways which school children can absorb. It cannot use the big words but simple, direct explanations, so it sinks in to the collective sub-conscious. If these efforts succeed, then democracy will take root in Singapore, and our democratic institutions can flourish.

    These five Shared Values are not the only ones which Singaporeans should hold in common. Nor are they intended to be writ in stone, unchangeable for all time. They must reflect the circumstances and priorities of the times. Each generation must adapt them and interpret them to suit their circumstances. But the Shared Values will provide a guide to help us from going astray. They offer a basis from which a Singaporean identity can in time emerge. I think the key words are "in time". We do not want to rush this, we do not want to force this. Let the values trickle down, seep

Column: 841

in, gradually be absorbed, transmuted and blossomed.

    There have been some suggestions to form a Committee to implement these values. I have some reservations on this. I asked my colleague, the Minister for Community Development, what MCD does on this score. He told me that, in fact, it is already doing a number of projects which are consistent with the Shared Values. It runs a Family Week, Family Life Education Programmes, Community Week, Senior Citizens' Week, Volunteer Month, 25th Anniversary Charity Fund - $88 million was collected last year, totally voluntary efforts - and, of course, there is the Feedback Unit, helping to generate a consensus. We should continue with these piecemeal gradual approaches rather than establish a Committee, develop action plans, and push through what may not yet be fully cooked.

    Dr Ong Chit Chung's motion asks the House to adopt the White Paper, not as The Shared Values for Singaporeans, but as the basis for developing a set of shared values for Singaporeans. There is a world of difference. I think Dr Ong has chosen the right approach - cautious rather than hasty, as guidelines rather than laws, and open-ended rather than final. I therefore urge Members to support the motion.

Column: 841

SHARED VALUES
(Motion)


    Debate resumed.

     Mr Lau Ping Sum (Yio Chu Kang)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the new year has brought us a new beginning. On the 2nd of January this year, our leaders presented this White Paper to lay the foundation for a stable and harmonious society. "Nation before community and society above self" is a basic tenet. Without territorial integrity and sovereignty, no country

Column: 842

can survive; its citizens will become refugees. During a SBC forum yesterday, the view was expressed that the Shared Values might be seen by some people as an attempt to discourage differing views. Moreover, the values seemed similar to communist slogans used by Eastern Europe to safeguard the interests of a few old men. In may view, the supremacy of nation is relevant to all countries. Even in Western democracies like the United States of America, the late President Kennedy once said: "Ask not what the country can do for you but ask first what you can do for the country." As regards the slogans of communist countries, they are not necessarily undesirable. Mao Zedong said, "Serve the People". I doubt any of my colleagues here will object to that.

    In the 80s', political and economic changes occurred rapidly. The restructuring of the Soviet and the Eastern European economies proves that the pursuit of wealth and a better life is not a daydream of the Bourgeoisie only. In fact, hard work and the search for a better life is the motivating force for progress. Improvement comes with competition. The market economy is driven by the human propensity to move upwards. However, in achieving personal goals we should not use all means, fair or foul. Otherwise, social disorder and escalating crime rates will follow.

    The pursuit of wealth is of course not wrong. But if people are obsessed by the desire to get rich quick and to get something for nothing, then we shall have to be very careful. In recent years, lucky draws have become very popular. Even statutory boards do not want to lag behind. In order to increase the usage of IDD, Telecom has also organised a lucky draw.

    In a bustling metropolis, some young people tend to go for branded clothes and accessories, showing off to one another their latest acquisitions. But in a small country with no natural resources, facing a slowdown or even a recession in the world economy, should we encourage and publicize a life of luxury and extravagance? According to Mr Peh Chin Hua, junior college students spend several hundred dollars for an evening dress for their

Column: 843

graduation dinner and dance, a sum which is probably greater than their monthly salary when they start work after leaving junior college.

    The White Paper states that we should preserve the values that have helped Singapore to succeed. The diligence and thrift of the pioneers was one of the main reasons for our success. They laboured under extremely trying conditions, eking out a living. Parents and older brothers and sisters made sacrifices, saving every dollar, so that their children and their siblings would have a better life through higher education. We cannot be sure that our economy will always do well. In a recession, will our people accept a simple life and difficult work? Expensive tastes and high consumption could be habit-forming, a habit which is going to be difficult to get rid of. The White Paper should therefore stress the importance of hard work and thrift.

    Then what is the concern? The concern among many people is that the call to put society above self must not be over-used. This vital instrument of state must not be perceived to be an instrument used simply to achieve administrative expediency. For example, everyone of us wants clean public toilets. What I am trying to say is that the need to entertain creates an inherent bias in the mass media towards individualism and towards the enhancement of self-interest.     As a small island state with Asian values, I agree with the Prime Minister and those who support the preparation of a statement on Shared Values that our competitiveness and our survival is best served if we can crystallise the essence of our shared values for ourselves and for coming generations of Singaporeans.
